description: The verb is derived from hood (“head covering attached to a larger garment such as a jacket or cloak”) +‎ wink (“to close one’s eyes”).
The noun is derived from the verb.

entries.meaning: (countable) An act of hiding from sight, or something that cloaks or hides another thing from view.
(Britain, games, obsolete, uncountable) The game of blind man's buff.

verbs.description: hoodwink (third-person singular simple present hoodwinks, present participle hoodwinking, simple past and past participle hoodwinked)

entries.meaning: (transitive, archaic) To cover the eyes with, or as if with, a hood; to blindfold. [from mid 16th c.]
To deceive using a disguise; to bewile, dupe, mislead.
(intransitive, obsolete, rare) To close the eyes.
